Agreed. I don't think Riot gets enough credit for how hard they work to make things balanced and fun for everyone. Things aren't perfect, but they're doing a way better job than I'm sure most of the whiners would do.
Hey, Skarner shouldn't be lonely, give him a roc-oh wait...

So what about situations where an item pushes a champ over the edge? AKA Sej and Cinderhulk or Release Devourer and Warwick?

These champions get nerfed, then the item gets nerfed...but no compensation. Sej is in a worse spot, as is sion, and yet nothing has been done to compensate them.

I get that it seems like we've forgotten about these guys, but the truth is that League has so many moving pieces that just because they didn't make the patch doesn't mean we didn't talk about where they're at. Sion/Sej maybe could use a tweak back upwards, but after having them be in such a dominant spot for several months it seems wrong to not give other champions some love too.

Okay, I'm going to call you out on this 

>but after having them be in such a dominant spot for several months it seems wrong to not give other champions some love too.

Thresh/Lee Sin have been in, if not "dominant", very popular for YEARS. Thresh hasn't been touched, and Lee Sin was giving a flat buff. (shockingly right before Worlds)

So how are Gragas/Rek/Lee/ect are allowed to be among the best for so long? But others are not.

(also the idea of "we didn't forget" and "maybe they could use a tweak but they were strong for a bit so we are keeping them down" don't seem to fit together)

I think these things are what drive those on G&B so crazy.

PS. You say 

>On the other hand, we also saw that Sion’s strength as a jungler was absolutely monstrous (close to a 60% win rate),

Yet ADC Morde is very close to that. And what nerfs did he get in the last patch?

http://www.lolking.net/champions/mordekaiser#statistics
Actually, he's averaging at a 50% win-rate with a low pick rate. Not only that, but the only time you see Mordekaiser dominating is when it's blind pick or somebody counter-picks with Mordekaiser. He's a champion that is still easily exploitable but nobody exploits his weaknesses still.

http://champion.gg/champion/Mordekaiser

And in the land of people who know what they're doing (Plat+ ranked) he's got a 58% winrate. And yes, that pick rate seems low, but that's because he has a 50% ban rate.

The issue is that people aren't properly counter-picking or counter-playing these champions. If anything, Darius is the only one of the Juggernauts that severely needs attention. So far, I've dealt with good players behind each of these champions and have come out successful with proper coordination or counter-picking. Not every champion is meant to counter every champion. I personally think it's a lack of understanding counter-play/picking that is resulting in the higher win-rates. (Also, sorry for the weird reply. It wouldn't let me reply to your post directly.)

Edit: Ranked has an average of 50% win-rate as well. It doesn't go until Master that it's at the absolute highest. That's also because, and I'm assuming, at this level of play people know how to exploit the strengths of champions and know how to protect the weaknesses of other champions, in this case, Mordekaiser.
The thing is, Morde (as an example) is something like 95% pick/ban at Worlds so far. If the "best of the best" ban him, it's not just as easy as "counter pick".

I don't think it's a secret that Riot loves keeping "playmakers" in the meta. It was obvious that when Sejauni had pro play, Riot strongly disliked her play pattern, along with the other cinderhulk tanks, being so dominant when she was strong because she has reliable engage and survivability (and would stagnate games). Lee on the other hand has all those fancy overloaded skills that look nice to watch and dash all over the screen with. The thinking that "other champs need love" pretty much confirms that they're ok forcing metas and dumpstering champions that haven't been as historically popular.

Lee Sin was out of pro play and had a pretty poor win rate when we gave him some buffs. Really he's a case of exactly what was being advocated for Sion/Sejuani - we nerfed this guy a lot, and we tried to give him something back. I think the trend has been similar for Thresh/Grag/Rek'sai, we've had a history of nerfing them a fair amount. If you'd like to call us out on getting to Lee Sin before Sion, that may be fair, although other factors that these two dev blogs have gotten into affect those decisions.

There's a good chance we do more follow-up on Morde soon. Guy is stronk.
I mean, we couldn't have worlds without lee sin dominating the jungle scene now could we?

Well, you succeeded. Lee Sin is now the most popular jungler in the game. Again.

Yay.
And yet you decide to buff Lee Sin when he never really went away.

In cases like that, I just wish they'd listen to us on the PBE where we post dozens (if not hundreds) of comments telling Riot to not actually release it because it's broken. And then they do it anyway. And then they disable or hotfix the thing, or the thing becomes 100% pick-or-ban for two weeks.

Don't think we're great at parsing PBE feedback. There's definitely been times where PBE have let us know of some impending doom that we didn't pay attention to; on the other hand, PBE universally regarded the Garen and Skarner changes as completely underpowered before they were released in 5.16. We need to step up our game a bit here.

True enough. Because the PBE players are basically just a sample from Live servers, you get just as much helpful feedback as you get whining.

I'm usually a salty whiner myself (see my post about Annie above), but I have a lucky track record of actually being right about things haha. I swear I'm like the only Ahri player who was actually _excited _about Patch 5.2 because I saw massive potential in it.

A massive contributing factor is match-ups.

In terms of balance on there or even the live boards, wouldn't you think gold - plat at a minimum would be necessary to discuss the state of the game?  I mean, I've been on the PBE and played a few pvp games and it's like I was playing against intermediate bots that call this and that overpowered or useless.  I don't feel confident that these people know the game well enough to talk about it.

I've heard from other game devs that in MoBas like LoL they over buff champions on purpose to change the meta when it is getting too stale. That it's not all that impossible to balance all the champions but that would kill the game.

I don't think there's a stable "balance" state that could ever exist in LoL, even theoretically. The landscape of the game is always being changed by new content we add (items, champions, reworks), so I'd say making sure the game isn't stale is one of our core values. That being said, we don't ever try to "over buff", sometimes we just miss.

Thanks for the response.  I do have to say,  and my group of friends that have been playing since season one agree, this season far and away has been the most diverse and entertaining to both play and watch.  Keep it up.
Most of the people who work on Live Gameplay are truly motivated by making a better game of League of Legends, so that's really awesome to hear.

>I don't think there's a stable "balance" state that could ever exist in LoL, 

Welp, you almost had it at the end of the cinderhulk meta, but flashy big plays are too important right?  Can't have the spectators "bored with the show" can we?  It's incredible how many champions were viable at one time, and how healthy and balanced the game was.  This was the most accepted meta we've had in years, and you fucked it up because the pro scene was boring to watch.  

Good job.

Oh and keep white knighting them, you're part of the problem.

Are you saying that a stable balance state is a desirable thing? You say stable, I say stagnant. A constantly evolving meta is one that allows for creativity, surprise, and excitement. Nothing makes me want to stop playing a game faster than the feeling that it's a competition between the the accepted strategies for the agreed-upon "best" characters. A game is no longer a game once it's been solved.

A stable state of balance where there are viable picks everywhere instead of the 15 or so  that everyone flocks to that we always seem to have?  Of course I want a stable state. It isn't stagnant when people are playing different champions.

I see what you did ther**e**.
And then there's Annie, with a 1315-unit-ranged instant AoE stun on a 40-second cooldown that can also one-shot kill most squishy targets.

Actually, her ult alone can't usually one shot squishy targets and more importantly the range of the ult is 600, going to 1025 if you add flash on top of that. Btw, flash has a 5 minute cool down, not a 40 second and that's the range you include in your statement.

So when do you guys see bringing balance back to champions like Heimerdinger{{champion:74}}. No, he's not OP or really all that dominant....out of the laning phase. In the laning phase however he's so oppressive I've decided to ban him in every game cause, point blank, it's just not fun to play against him. Even if he falls off late game, early game he can pretty much 1v2/3 an entire team just by letting his turrets do all the work, and since he's ALWAYS got turrets up he's always going to win trades(I've yet to see him lose a trade even when the jungler ganks while he's in lane doing his thing). I don't know what the cooldown of those things are, but as soon as I'm able to get rid of one, another comes right back up almost instantly. Are they set on charges like Teemo's Shrooms/Zyra's plants? If so, I feel like with their enhancement when you reworked him that it might have been an oversight, cause no matter who I'm playing with against him I can't do anything against him in lane. Even Syndra, soon as I grab a turret, he's got another one up to replace it, making whatever counterplay there is against him(which is getting him away from his turrets) null and void. I want to re-iterate, I'm not saying the champion is OP, or that he's even in a healthy state(If anything I feel like he might be in an unhealthy state at the moment). What I'm saying is his laning phase is the oppressiveness that I feel you've stated you want to avoid, because as far as I can tell and have tried multiple times, there's simply no counterplay against him in lane, and again, key word here: In lane.

Keep up the good work though, enjoying(most) of what you guys put out.

With you that Heimer's lane play pattern can feel very oppressive. We pretty frequently have the discussion on whether he could use some adjustments there. There are still some major kit-level issues we could work to resolve (specifically, for both Heimer and his opponents to understand and appreciate the threat conveyed by his turrets), but they're definitely complex problems.

One thing that could help bring more counterplay to Heimerdinger in laning would be to allow his turrets be subject to cc effects. I already have a few strategies I use when laning against Heimerdnger, but as I was experimenting and working these out, I noticed that his mini turrets are not subject to any debuffs, unlike minions or jungle monsters. 

It's already "unfair" that his turrets persist after he dies (going all-in on Heimey, only to give up a double or triple kill to him because he still has that one damn turret shooting away). This "life-after-death" is really only present on a few champions, and these cases also have a good thematic and explicit reason to be there as part of their kits (Sion, Karthus, Zyra, etc.).

post death is looked over so much on him, but it gives him so much power, especially since his turrets can charge those longer range piercing lasers. Zyra plants have a range and attack speed limit and her passive has a delay and is a hit or miss. Sions passive has a delay and is close ranged. Both sion and zyra have giant theatrical windups. Karthus has a very small delay and is limited by range and cooldowns (to produce continuous damage vs continuous attacking from turrets).Those other three all lose a potentially lane functional passives to live longer. Heim loses nothing to have post death play. He gets his normal laning passive and his R gives him long range poke, huge stun, or a mega turret that also has mega post death value. Honestly I find what makes heims post game so overpowered is how stable and sustained it is (v zyra and sion) and how little the rest of his kit sacrifices to have post game play. These other guys are made around their post game play, where heims feels like a bonus on top of the rest of his kit, and it gets really oppressive...

I think that's a really good point to make.

Heimer's turrets give him as much, if not more post death power than Zyra, especially given that Zyra's plants scale with level.
